RT @west_wave_: https://t.co/kEpUYp4Ypq
a good day in Chicago
the elevators also had men in them! one put his arm across the door so you wouldn't fall out. there wasn't a door.
he grimmaced when he told us the price, knowing it'd be too much. "you say you can do a simpler job for less, but then you end up just doing the same work for half the price"

this is after we visited a luthier cuz @nidobun's violin has a crack. he was a nice man, too! big, in an apron. bandage on his middle finger. at first I thought he must be an apprentice. he said no, he'd started the shop himself!

nice wood on shelves
as I was checking out the skinny man asked me, do you read tabulature. I said not really, he showed me a book with elaborate tabulature for a weird lute. this is the GOOD tab, he said

when he was looking for the cage manuscript, he had to ask an older, taller, skinnier man where they had put it. "clarinet" said the skinny man. I got the sense that they put it in a different category each time they got one in stock

Lastly, I got a classical piece, The Swan" that the man pointed out to me cuz of the Clara Rockmore video he'd seen on youtube. Rockmore is the most famous thereminist! He asked, can you read music? I answered, badly!

this sort of thing happens all the time when you read the old stuff. Often it's buried in the pages upon pages of stuff that you're (I'm) like wtf is this part even for, why include all of this? what work is it doing?
So when Holmes was talking about rolling 2 20-sided dice to get percentile values, HE WAS STRAIGHTFORWARDLY CORRECT and my knowledge was the thing out of synch
turns out they're talking about the then-common type of d20s that were numbered 1-10 TWICE. So just, a more spherical d10. Why? Dunno, requires more research.
wtf is going on, I think to myself, wtfuckingchrist is going on, I wonder
at the end of the section there's a paragraph that clarifies you're supposed to take the 20-sided dice and mark (some of?) the faces with a red marker, and the red marked faces represent N+10.
case in point, a part in Holmes Basic where it describes rolling two 20-sided dice to get a percentile value. I thought, "that must just be a typo, obvs he means d10s"

stumble around a few hashtags and find more information, and perspectives from people with other relationships to this history than I do. 

In closing, here's my favorite song that relates to all of this. The picture includes Hans and Sofie Scholl:

https://t.co/r7csTwhe56

So, these are some of the idiosyncratic things I have been thinking about while remembering the Holocaust, its perpetrators, its victims, and the macro-/national and micro-/personal forces that create and de-create such events. If any of this interests you, today's a good day to

Since I'm talking about monuments, let's not forget about the Memorial to the Unknown Deserter (Potsdam, Germany), which has been rattling around in the back of my head for years: 

https://t.co/LysZmxgLsc

Today I read about the Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe (also in Berlin), which I don't think I had ever seen pictures of before! Like with the memorial to homosexuals, this literal monument has a fraught history of interpretation, check it out: https://t.co/jiOqgymAWO
Here's info about the Memorial to Homosexuals Persecuted Under Nazism (in Berlin): https://t.co/gj58PXLKGF

homosexuals killed by the Nazis. It's a book that I am getting a LOT out of re: my bigger interests in gay memory and nostalgia and counter-narratives and evaporating gay sex spaces. Let's say it's a book about Rememberance, if not about the Holocaust.

https://t.co/HC1ABbRWdS

I'm reading IF MEMORY SERVES, which is not directly about the Holocaust but is about memory and anti-memory in the lives of (mostly white) gay men, mostly re: AIDS. This afternoon I'm going to read the chapter on memorials, which includes a section about the memorial to

Right now I am reading BEING PRESENT, a history-via-memoire, written by a non-Jewish German who was six years old when Hitler took power. It is about indoctrination, complicit family, and normalization and education inside a totalitarian regime.

https://t.co/pHGMoiTvLI

on the inside; about propaganda and lies and pretending. About radicalization and neo-Nazis. A complicated, troubling, problematic, compelling story. 

https://t.co/JySHLJ7eSo

I read Kurt Vonnegut's novel MOTHER NIGHT, which is about an American who becomes a spy for the American government; he becomes a high-profile propagandist for the Nazis, sending secret signals in the midst of his anti-Semitic and nationalist rhetoric. About guilt and working
DEFYING HITLER: https://t.co/f1Qcm3aNAi

non-Jewish Germans choose or are forced into some sort of complicit working relationship with the Nazi regime. I've been thinking a lot about Hans and Sophie Scholl, both of whom were killed by the Nazis for resisting--and both of whom had been active in Hitler Youth.

Recently I've been reading DEFYING HITLER, which is about Jews and non-Jews resisting the Third Reich through direct sabotage, assassination attempts, or dissemination of information. My idea for the game centers on these sorts of stories, especially those in which

I really liked THE LANGUAGE OF THIEVES. About itinerate and poor people in Europe and their use of subaltern language and, about the author learning about his grandfather's life as a Nazi bureaucrat and "race scientist"

https://t.co/ewvdQ21BvT

Next I read KILLING QUEERS, the troubling memoire of a homosexual man who became a kapo and "lover" (his word; complicated!) to several concentration camp guards, in order to stay alive.

https://t.co/HINUWuBBU1

Along these lines, check out @badgayspod, a great podcast about complicated queer people in history. Check out the episodes on Philipp, Prince of Eulenberg (pre-Third Reich), Ernst vom Rath (a Nazi diplomat assassinated by Herschel Grynszpan), and Ernst Röhm, noted gay Nazi.

It's not about the Holocaust per se but talks about the intellectual mood of the times that led to the rise of the Nazis, with specific reference to the precursors to the Nazis' cult of masculinity and sexual hardness and military force. HIGHLY recommended.

Okay! Some specific stuff to check out that I thought was interesting: I got into the topic after reading Robert Beachy's GAY BERLIN. It's about the Weimar Republic and early political identity formation among "homophiles" and "homosexuals."

https://t.co/5cz6Zjgnkn

Generally: Today's a great day to read work and history and memoire by Jews! And Sinti and Roma people! And political radicals! And incarcerated people! And contemporary anti-Fascist organizers! Hell Yeah!

Note: If it isn't clear, my interests are in the gay and trans experiences of the Holocaust, and, to a growing degree, in the stories of non-Jewish Germans living under totalitarian rule. Which is only one part of a much bigger story, obviously. I am a non-Jewish gay man.

So! Instead of trying to explain a bunch of my thoughts and feelings, I'm just going to link you to some things that I have been reading or thinking about. Maybe one of these things will be inspiring or thought-provoking to you, too.

That's where I am with this game.

"All these ideas" are about empire and censorship and totalitarianism and sabotage and failure and remembering and complicity and resistance and imagining. That's where I am with my Holocaust Remembering, that whole word cloud.

it's the way I know how to get at all these ideas. I think it's an Ursula K. Le Guin quote where she says people kept asking her to talk about anarchism, and she said something like, "I kept trying, and it came out as a novel. Go read that if you want to know what I think."

@symatt It's hard to carry a lot of tubes around. Only trained professionals should carry more than a few tubes.
@symatt You have to wash the tubes between uses, they get gunky.

@symatt To cast a spell the spell has to go through an abstract tube--the slot. A small spell can go through small tubes or big tubes, but a big spell can only go through big tubes. Sometimes, when you put a small spell through a big tube, the tube amplifies it into a big spell!

thank you for reading this art ramble
"but what's the HYPOTHESIS" I dunno gimme a fucking research grant and maybe I could come up with such a thing. This is art that I think is good, in a room, for you to look at.

For my last show people would ask me what it was "about" and I would say, "I tried to meet as many textile artists in Chicago as I could, and I put them all in the show." and art people couldn't swallow it

You can't write "This piece is in the show because my friend made it and I think it looks nice, especially next to this other piece I also chose from another friend of mine." And yet, like, that's the truth.

"okay but what can you say that's NEW about it, something that will engage the art press?" listen folks I'm writing this intro text for my mother, not some fucking art institute lecturer, do you want me to be a marketer or to say the actual literal actual truth about what i do

a weirdness at the center of curatorial writing is that one both must and cannot say the obvious thing

"it's abstract art" is both a basic fact that one must say, and also exactly what the industry wants you to not say; this is one of the reasons behind bloated art speak

@gaghyogi49 "You all close the caves of No'Mat!" would properly be:

no'mat 'ochmey tISoQmoH!

@gaghyogi49 I think your transcription is wrong, I think it is <'ochmey tISoQ no'mat>

I haven't seen the episode so I'll trust that no'mat is a name. <'ochmey tISoQ> almost means "You all close the tunnels" (but it is lacking a necessary grammar ending).

@gaghyogi49 I can't tell in this image if it uses a q or a Q. (This capitalization is important in Klingon writing.) It should be a Q, and QI'tu' should have a final apostrophe. And ghe'tor is just misspelled.

@gaghyogi49 I think you are right in this image that the designer is going for something like <ghe'tor QI'tu'> but--classic mistake!--they have mixed up the symbol for the vowel I (as in "ice") with the consonant "l" (as in "lemon")

@gaghyogi49 Hi, I'm a Klingon "expert" cert'd through the Klingon Language Institute! Glad to see you had fun trying to puzzle out the writing in these images! Unfortunately, the writing has all the signs of someone trying to write in Klingon without really knowing what they were doing.

Then, just as a solar eclipse empowers their opponents' faerie magic, the duo faces The Beauties in a dice game. Giant magical Witnesses save Thomas from an impossible gamble when they destroy Flora the Witch for cheating.

Later, when a would-be initiate steals the fabled Tablet of Issachar to win favor with The Beauties, Thomas trades his Fool's Stone to secure the tablet... but at what cost? Robert makes an unholy pact with the Mandrakes and becomes Steward of the Stone.

Tonight! On #London1666!

Am I witnessing the generation of literally the first recording of two people speaking two different dialects to each other? Probably. That's hot.

Klingon (like they think it's a thing any random Trekkie can do) but that's not true. There are, generously, 100 people on the planet that can have any level of convo in the language. Maybe 10 people can passably do it in one of the "dialects."

This is one of the things I cherish about this whole Klingon thing---there are literally two people alive who could do this sort of language play, and, well, here they are doing it. Lotsa people think there are a TON of people who can speak and understand...
